body:
- Which version do you use?
- -1 means no substring found.
- 6 in array `bytes` of your method `test004()` is a byte which will be interpreted `\u0006` in AsciiString, while "6" is a string  whose ascii value is `\u0036`. Combination of these two fact means the result is -1 even if the method `lastIndexOf` is bug free.
- `byte[] bytes =  new byte['1', '2', '3', '4', '5', '6', '7', '8', '9'] ` may be what you want.
@xiaoheng1 You're right. I also checked the source code. This should be an issue, I will do PR later.

issue.title: AsciiString.lastIndexOf(...) is implemented incorrectly

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation

@xiaoheng1 reported incorrect behaviour of `AsciiString.lastIndexOf` in #9099. Upon closer inspection it appears that it was never implemented correctly and searches between the provided index and the end of the string similar to `indexOf(CharSequenct, int)`, rather than between the provided index
and the beginning of the string as the javadoc states (and in line with `java.lang.String`).

Modifications

Fix `AsciiString.lastIndexOf` implementation and corresponding unit tests to behave the same as the equivalent `String` method.

Result

Fixes #9099

body: Thanks @xiaoheng1, have opened #9103 to address this.

issue.title: AsciiString.of("/foo).lastIndexOf("/") returns -1

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
### Expected behavior
AsciiString.of("/foo").lastIndexOf("/") = 0

### Actual behavior
AsciiString.of("/foo").lastIndexOf("/") = -1

### Netty version
4.1.36.Final

### JVM version (e.g. `java -version`)
java version "11.0.3" 2019-04-16 LTS
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment 18.9 (build 11.0.3+12-LTS)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM 18.9 (build 11.0.3+12-LTS, mixed mode)

### OS version (e.g. `uname -a`)
4.15.0-50-generic #54-Ubuntu SMP Mon May 6 18:46:08 UTC 2019 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
